captions.text:
Here at Arcade Arms,
we take the raddest video game
weapons and we forge them—in real life!

With, like, metal and bone
and gnarly bits.

And then we take that weapon
that used to be just

numbers and pixels
and we smash the crap out of stuff.
We help dreams come true.

In this episode,
we are going to the land of Tamriel
in the game Elder Scrolls Online.

And we are going to discover
the dark secrets of

a certain Daedric Prince
and his weapon of doom:
the Mace of Molag Bal.
So what makes this weapon so cool?
We sat down with Lawrence Schick,
the Lead Loremaster at Bethesda,
to get the scoop.
We decided for Elder Scrolls Online

that the world-threatening menace was
going to be the Daedric Prince

Molag Bal, who just hates
the mortals of Tamriel
and wants to enslave and dominate them all.

There are a number of
very powerful artifacts,

and among the most notorious of all
is the Mace of Molag Bal.

Molag Bal tricked this Orcish smith
and brought him to Coldharbour

where he stole his soul,
made him one of his Soul Shriven,

and forced him to forge
the Mace of Molag Bal.
When it strikes an enemy,

it vampirically sucks stamina and
magicka from the target
and gives it to the wielder.

Molag Bal loves to meddle
with the lives of mortals,
and so he grants his mace to them

if they prove themselves
worthy to bear it.

'Cause he assumes that,
as a natural result of having

The Vampire's Mace,
there’s going to be a trail of death,

destruction, murder, and mayhem
behind whoever is wielding it.
<b>SERVE ME AND DESTROY THE MORTALS.</b>
We scoured the globe

to find a forge master
who can make
this incredibly impossible weapon.
And we found him
in New Brunswick, Canada
in the middle of freezing-ass winter.
I'm Jake Powning.
I'm a swordsmith and weapon maker…

...and student of ancient material
culture and...

...weapons in mythology
and ancient stories.

Well, the Mace of Molag Bal
implies a very dark mythology.

I mean, if you look at the face on it,
it's actually a human skull with...

...insect pincers
coming out of its mouth.

I look at pictures of characters
in the game holding it,
and it’s about 36 inches long
if the characters are six feet tall.
Mm-hmm.

So then I went in and
measured the actual image,
and then I scaled it up using math.
Math!
Yeah.
Math is the stuff with numbers...
Magic.
...right?
Yeah.
Okay.
Math and magic? Both?
Exact-well.
It's pretty much the same thing to me.
Not to me!
No, no. We have to fight now.

So, I'm using the same strategy
to create the…

...the real mace that the designers
used to create the digital mace.
It's basically constructed as one side
that's repeated four times.

So this is the mace model
in plasticine.
And plasticine is, like...
...it's kind of...squishy?
Yeah, it's like a...it's clay.
Oh!
So, but it doesn't harden.
Oh, it happens to a lot of maces.
Um...I wanna give it a try.

Um, but I want to use
the scary dentist tool.
Because...because reasons.

So, basically I made...um...
a plasticine mace in a form,
and then made a rubber mold of that.
Now I can melt wax
and pour the wax into the mold,

and I'll have a copy
of the plasticine model.
Once I've cast three more of these,

I can put them together
and construct a mace.
Now I can shape the wax, and carve it,
and make the mace

exactly the way I want it to look
in bronze.
So this is the mace in its wax form,
and it's like a baseball bat

which are...you know an
aluminum baseball bat is hollow?

Do you see the resemblance
between me and this

frightening, like, skull...
vampire beast?
Do my teeth that way—grrr!
Once I had the...the wax constructed,
I made molds of the wax.

Once that's hardened,
you melt the wax out.

This is an extremely challenging
and frightening period

because you've destroyed
the thing you've made

until you pour the bronze in
and it fills the space.

The bronze is cooled front down
so it's a black heat—

it's still hot, but
it's not glowing red anymore.

So I take the mold
and quench it in water.

Then you have a bronze object
exactly the shape of the wax.

We'll carve out the details and
make sure that everything is just so.
Oh my...

Wow!
That looks like a two-hander to me.
<i>That's what she said.</i>

Alright!
Let's go break some stuff!
Thirty...five...pounds?
Are you kidding me?
<b>YOU ENTERTAIN ME MORTAL!</b>
<b>NOW, ENTERTAIN ME MORE.</b>

So now that I've
slipped a disc in my back,

we want to see exactly
what this weapon can do.
And we found just the guy to do it.

He is a Marine veteran,
and a founder of the USA Knights,

which is an organization of people
who dress up in plate armor
and beat the hell out of each other
...you know, for fun.
My name is Andre Sinou.

I'm the team captain
of the USA Knights,

which is our national
sword fighting team.
We wear armor.

We're out there, full force,
full contact.
My preferred weapon is a mace.

Having something that's kinda
short and heavy
and powerful like that—

it gives you the edge
on the battlefield.

Well the mace is a, uh,
it's a mass weapon.

We call it a mass weapon because
it does trauma at a point of impact—
uh, more so than a sword.

A lot of times when
a sword hits armor,

the impact gets spread out
across the armor,

where a mace will actually transfer
that impact through the armor.

Uh, the idea behind a mace is to
scramble somebody's
eggs inside their helmet.

Right here,
these two are called flanged maces.
Uh, this mace is called a bar mace—

it doesn’t have anything
to puncture armor—

it's just the mass
of the weapon itself.
Uh, this is a very potent weapon.

I actually broke somebody's femur
with this through their armor.

What would you consider the
mace of a Daedric Prince to be like?

This has got a lot more weight.
This is about 35 pounds.

Uh, would I want to swing this
one-handed all day long?
Probably not—you'd get worn out.
What kind of damage could this do?

Well, if I could swing a
35-pound weapon single-handedly—

something of this size—uh
there'd be nothing you could do to stop me.

I mean, you'd put your
arm up with your shield,

I'd probably break your arm through
your shield in the first blow—

if you were able
to block the first one.

The second one's gonna
take your head clean off.

So...do you think
you wanna try it out?
I sure do.
Alright, let's do this!
So no more Mr. Nicey-nice.

We're gonna see what
the mace can really do.
Take it, Andre.

This is what happens
when a mace hits ya.

So that's...what? I dunno.
A fractured rib or two?
But let's see what Molag Bal can do.
<b>TIME TO TORTURE SOME MORTALS.</b>

You just...
...turned it...jelly!
Ah—this is gonna be real fun.

You know, I think I could grow
to like something like this.
Are you ready to scramble some eggs?
Yeah, let's do this.

Wanna do something a
little more modern?
I'm up for anything.

That's what it felt like
when they canceled <i>Firefly</i>.

So are you ready to become
a human wrecking-ball?
The steam's up—let's do this.

Yes! Were gonna take down that fortress.
Now, charge!

I wish I was tall enough
to actually handle it.

It's just a massive weapon.
I don't know what to do.

Well listen, uh, Nika,
I brought you a little present today.
I got a little something for you.
<i>I got a dollhouse?</i>

You ready young lady?
To smash up a dollhouse?

I don't think I've ever
been more ready in my life.
Alright. One. Two. Three!

<b>YOUR SOUL IS MINE!
I OWN YOU!</b>
<b>COME, LET US PLAY.</b>
I feel...different.

I think...
I need...to hurt things.

I need...
I need to hurt a lot of things.
Kill...kill...kill!
Kill! KILL!
YOU'VE DONE WELL. FEAST.

So now we know the story and the lore
behind the Mace of Molag Bal.
And in fact, we created it,

and then we just busted up
a bunch of stuff with it.

And all it really cost us was having the
voice of a Daedric Prince

in our head, talking about
destruction all the time!

But that's not really
different than normal.

So tune in next time,
and maybe we'll kill a dragon!
With a spoon!
But...probably not.

comments.author: Guest0ne

comments.text:
You guys fucked up.

You cast the mace of Molag Bal in Bronze, a soft metal you can bend OVER 
YOUR KNEE. And unless I'm blind, I didn't see any tempering or sharpening 
of the flanges, which were bent to hell by the end of the video.

TWO, THE MACE OF MOLAG BAL, HAS -- THREE -- SIDES, NOT FOUR! HOW DID YOU 
EVEN DO THAT!? CLEARLY YOU DIDN'T KEEP AN EYE ON YOUR SOURCE MATERIAL.

-Vladimir Lastraud

P.S. The Mace of Molag Bal is one of my favorite weapons in the elder 
scrolls, to see it made so shoddily, and INACCURATELY, is somewhat 
insulting to me and obviously the subject matter.﻿

comments.author: Gabbo Gav

comments.text:
*Shrug* Maybe I just hold too much respect for the subject matter that I 
just don't like how it was handled at the end of the day. If it was me, I 
would be that guy that took several weeks or months to get it perfect.

As a sidenote: The main thing I held this to as a comparison was "Man at 
Arms" and it has unfortunately been revealed to me that that series is 
over, apparently Tony, main guy of the show, owner of sword and the stone, 
didn't like his relation to the media group he had the contract under.
comments.author: Vladimir Lastraud

comments.text:
+Vladimir Lastraud May there be better ways to do this? Perhaps. An artist 
could spend days or even weeks bent over a block of steel painstakingly 
scraping the metal away with steel-cutting tools to faithfully recreate the 
mace with a better material like steel. But considering that the intended 
use for this was to smash a few things and then likely be placed on a shelf 
for a long time, I'm happy with the result and I don't feel that I wasted 
my time watching this 10 minute video.
comments.author: Jack Rizzio

comments.text:
Y'know, I'll concede that there isn't a easily available metal outside of 
bronze, steel and iron casting taking more equipment that would be readily 
available in most black smiths, and due to it's fantasy origins, it's 
overly large weighs a motherfucker. That said, I suppose looking back my 
biggest beef is that knowing their limitations in the materials. ( Or at 
least I hope they did. ) I personally, if I had no other choice of 
material, would have left it from there, hung it up, and left it be on a 
spinning table yata yata. But they didn't, they took an item that for all 
purposes should have remained a shelf ornament and bashed it into concrete 
when as I mentioned before has several protruding smaller edges that were 
subsequently bent over and damaged. It feels to me the limitations were 
known and someone on high with less knowledge about the situation said. 
"Fuck it, smash some stuff."

Also, it weighed in around 34 pounds, with solid chunks of metal, I'd wager 
that if the molds were carved out from behind somewhat, and put into a full 
cast as opposed to the corners they were, it would be significantly 
lighter. And while yes, bronze is more likely the easiest thing to cast out 
of, but other tougher metals like iron or steel do exist, that would have 
far less of a problem bending over, even with reduced materials.

Not saying in a million years this thing could be made to historical or any 
realistic standards. But if you can straight face stand there and tell me 
this is the pinnacle of effort someone could do with this, then I'd call 
you a liar.

(Also yes, Three sides not four, that too, would reduce the weight.)

-Vladimir Lastraud
comments.author: Vladimir Lastraud

comments.text:
+Vladimir Lastraud Oh look, an actual source with real information about 
bronze maces, from a question by yours truly:
http://www.romanarmytalk.com/25-allies-a-enemies-of-rome/322285-flanged-maces.html

You shouldn't take a weapon like this seriously - THIRTY POUNDS does not 
make a viable battlefield weapon. HEMA practitioners will mostly agree that 
anything above eight pounds is just too heavy and unwieldy, even for 
armor-piercing weapons. 

On to making me repeat myself - they had to use bronze, because you cannot 
hammer steel into such shapes that the mace of Molag Bal has. Unless, of 
course, you want to try. You can, however, cast bronze into a mould as they 
did and it will not be shitty. Bronze does not get nearly the same work 
hardening benefits that steel does, but it is much easier to make bronze 
tools as you just melt the bronze and pour it into a mould instead of 
hammering it. 

THAT is why they used bronze. There were no other viable options.
comments.author: Jack Rizzio

comments.text: +CradleCrush Rock Giant Danke.
comments.author: Vladimir Lastraud

comments.text: +Vladimir Lastraud Heh. Nice comback.
comments.author: TinyThyMeluhn The III

comments.text:
That doesn't mean it's above criticism, especially when there are such 
glaring flaws. I doesn't matter if bronze isn't a terrible metal, it's 
soft, and they used it for a flanged mace, two things that should not be 
done together if it can be avoided. I may not be a metallurgist, but I know 
enough that I was able to see these most BASIC problems. So I won't "Shut 
up" as to pipe down just because someone got offended over my opinion is 
the kind of thing that starts inequality in the world where men rule 
through fear.

Piss off.

Sincerely, Vladimir Lastraud.
comments.author: Vladimir Lastraud

comments.text:
The reason the used a bronze cast was because there's really no way you can 
forge something like that. Bronze is not a terrible metal, further - yeah, 
you can bend a strip of it over, but it was made by someone who I'm willing 
to bet knows more about metallurgy then you do. If you think you can do 
better, by all means go for it. Until then, shut up because being a 
blacksmith is fuck as all hell hard, let alone a weapon smith.
comments.author: Jack Rizzio

comments.text:
+Vladimir Lastraud Yup, that four sided shit also made me flip a table, but 
other than that I can work with this. It would've looked better if it was 
made out of a dark iron or steel, but it would weigh too much.
comments.author: TinyThyMeluhn The III

comments.text:
Most of it I can chalk up to "It's enough" or it would have been too much 
work to make it out of another material. But the four sided thing drives me 
nuts.

comments.text:

neither could I. This guy tried his best and I haven't seen a better model 
made by any blacksmith. And it even took them a long time to even find a 
blacksmith that could forge this in a good looking manner. Now, stop 
judging and split a skull in half with The Mace Of Molag Bal. Also remember

dildo to make vampires O.o, as we all know how Serena became a vampire.

comments.author: Corinn Heathers

comments.text:
+Corinn Heathers I mean seriously, to even compare an MMO to a singleplayer 
game is fucking stupid.
No one gives a shit about how 'fantastic' you think Skyrim was.
I think Morrowind was 100% better, but dude stop comparing MMOs to 
singleplayer games.
It gets on my nerves and really ticks me off, if you think you should make 
your opinion about ESO public then sure go ahead.
But for the love of Christ, why'd you do that on this video.
It doesn't even contain gameplay.
